content.text: Once upon a time, long, long ago, there lived a wise and just king who was known far and wide for his wisdom.
But there was one thing about him that no one could understand—every day, after the royal dinner was cleared away, a trusted servant would bring him a covered dish.
No one ever saw what was inside, and the king always ate it alone in his chamber.
The servants whispered among themselves, wondering what secret food the king could be eating.
Now, among the king’s servants was a young man named Hans, who was kind-hearted and curious.
He often wondered about the mysterious dish, and one evening, when the king had left the dining hall, Hans could resist no longer.
He crept into the king’s chamber, lifted the silver lid of the dish, and peered inside.
To his astonishment, there lay a white snake, sliced into small pieces.
Hans had heard tales of magical creatures, and his heart raced with excitement.
Without thinking, he reached out and took a tiny bite of the snake.
The moment the morsel touched his tongue, a strange thing happened—he could suddenly understand the language of animals!
A pair of sparrows outside the window were chattering, and Hans heard them say, *"Oh, what a mess the cook has made in the kitchen!
The queen’s golden ring has fallen into the drain!"* Hans hurried to the kitchen and found the ring just as the sparrows had said.
He returned it to the queen, who was overjoyed and rewarded him with a handsome sum of gold.
But Hans was not content to stay in the palace.
He longed for adventure, so he asked the king for a horse and some money to travel the world.
The king, pleased with his honesty, granted his request.
Hans set off on his journey, riding through forests and over hills, listening to the animals he passed along the way.
One day, as he rode through a dense forest, he heard a terrible commotion.
A group of ants were in a panic, their anthill crushed by a fallen tree.
*"Oh, no!"* cried the ant king.
*"Our home is destroyed, and our eggs will be lost!"* Hans quickly dismounted and carefully lifted the tree away, saving the ants and their eggs.
The ants scurried about in gratitude, promising to help him if ever he needed them.
Further along his journey, Hans came to a wide lake where three fish were flopping helplessly on the shore, gasping for water.
*"We’re stuck!"* they cried.
*"The waves carried us here, and we can’t get back!"* Hans scooped them up gently and returned them to the lake.
The fish splashed their tails in thanks and called out, *"We won’t forget your kindness!"*  At last, Hans arrived in a great city where the king had a beautiful daughter.
The princess was wise and fair, but she had a strange custom—any man who wished to marry her had to complete a task she set for him.
Many had tried and failed, and those who failed were sent away in disgrace.
Hans, though he had no thought of marriage, was curious and decided to try his luck.
The princess led him to a vast hall filled with thousands of grains of wheat, barley, and rye, all mixed together in a great heap.
*"If you can sort these grains by tomorrow morning,"* she said, *"I will marry you.
But if you fail, you will be banished from the kingdom."*  Hans stared at the impossible task and sighed.
How could anyone sort so many grains in one night?
But as he sat down in despair, he heard a faint rustling sound.
The ant king he had saved in the forest appeared with an army of ants behind him.
*"Do not worry, friend,"* said the ant king.
*"We will help you."* And so, the ants set to work, sorting the grains with incredible speed.
By dawn, every single grain was in its proper place.
The princess was astonished, but she was not yet ready to give up.
She led Hans to the edge of a deep lake.
*"If you can fetch me the golden ring from the bottom of this lake,"* she said, *"I will marry you.
But if you fail, you will leave this land forever."*  Hans looked at the dark water and shook his head.
How could he find a ring in such a vast lake?
But just then, the three fish he had saved swam to the surface. *"We will help you,"* they said.
One of them dove deep and returned with the golden ring in its mouth.
Hans took the ring and presented it to the princess, who could hardly believe her eyes.
Still, the princess had one last task.
She led Hans to a high mountain where an old, gnarled tree stood.
*"If you can bring me an apple from the Tree of Life that grows on this mountain,"* she said, *"I will marry you.
But if you fail, you will never see me again."*  Hans climbed the mountain, but the tree was guarded by a fierce dragon.
Just as he was about to turn back in fear, he heard a hissing sound.
The white snake from the king’s dish slithered down from the branches.
*"I am the spirit of the Tree of Life,"* it said.
*"You have a kind heart, and I will help you."* The snake coiled around the dragon’s neck, putting it to sleep, and Hans plucked the golden apple from the tree.
When he returned to the princess with the apple, she smiled at last.
*"You have passed all my tests,"* she said.
*"You are truly the one I have been waiting for."* And so, Hans and the princess were married in a grand celebration, and they lived happily ever after.
As for the white snake, it is said that whoever eats a piece of it gains the power to understand the language of animals.
But Hans never took another bite—he had learned that kindness and wisdom were the greatest magic of all.
